reviewText: This movie is a good representation of what American used to be like and in some ways it still is.  I think that the innocence of the US culture and society that is portrayed in this film has disappeared somehow.  The ease of gaining employment will not return in our lifetime.  However, the genuine and welcoming attitudes of just regular people is represented so well here. The diversitiy of American people is also well represented.  People respect each other as individuals. I get emotional when Robin plays the saxaphone. I really did not know who he was or was really interested in him.  This film is one of Robin Williams' best.

reviewText: Now, this is the Robin Williams I love! I love Vladimir Ivanoff, saxophone player with the Moscow Circus. His friend, the clown of the circus, keeps talking about when they go on their trip to New York, he's going to defect. Vladimir tells him not to talk about it, that he (Vladimir) was obligated to report it to the authorities. "I could be KGB," he says. When they get to New York, it turns out they are assigned to share a hotel room. Vladimir says that's because the KGB has told him to spy on his friend.Their last stop before going to the airport to return to Moscow is Bloomingdale's. The clown has a KGB agent following him closely, and cries that he cannot do it. Suddenly, Vladimir decides to defect. He had been flirting with Lucia (Maria Conchita Alonso), the Italian sales clerk at the perfume counter, so now he hides behind her counter under her skirt! When Lionel Witherspoon (Cleavant Derricks), the security guard responsible for that area, tries to break up the chaos surrounding the KGB agents looking for Vladimir, Vladimir tells him "I want to defect." Police are called, they tell the KGB to get lost, a couple of FBI agents show up, and when they find he has no relatives or friends in New York, ask "Where's he going to sleep?" Lionel volunteers to take him home with him.No, I'm not going to tell you the whole story. Vladimir gets a lawyer first thing, because immigration lawyer Orlando Ramirez (Alejandro Rey) pushes through the crowd to give Vladimir his business card. So there's no particular issue of his being chased by the KGB, but the FBI tails him. Lionel explains that they are just doing that to be sure he's not a spy, and to protect him from the KGB.Vladimir works at various low-level jobs, rents an apartment, and invites Lucia up to see it. What he really wants to do is get work playing his saxophone. He bought one in a hock shop because his was left on the bus that the other Russians took to the airport. Of course, his neighbors complain when he plays it.The part that choked me up is the scene that never fails to choke me up: new citizens taking the oath of citizenship. Lucia is now an American! Next thing you know, she's fighting with Vladimir. But he gets his authentic initiation to New York soon after: he is mugged.Of course it ends happily. Robin Williams movies usually do. This is a charming, very funny film which, among other things, shows just how sexy Robin Williams can be . . . or was in 1984, anyway.
summary: Funny on a Lot of Levels

reviewText: Unfortunately, the copy I bought from the Amazon seller was in PAL and I had to buy another. My mistake. At any rate, while it's dated, this story shows the life of a Russian man who risks everything to be a "free man" in America by defecting in Macy's while on tour in New York. Life isn't much different in the U.S. than he knew in the Soviet Union, but he is in America, the land of opportunity, and learns what making one's own life really means. I like this film very much. Some gratuitous nudity and fondling that I felt wasn't necessary, so be aware if you're showing this film to a "mixed" audience (like family), but worth watching.
summary: An interesting film. It shows a side of life we don't often see.

reviewText: I don't always agree with Robin Williams' standup humor but IMAO, he is a consumate actor bordering on dramatic and comedic genius.  In this film he convincingly potrays a Russian circus musician that follows thru the dreams of his close friend by defecting to America.What strikes in my mind about this film is when his girlfriend and many immigrants are granted U.S. citizenship.  With the current state of today's political correctness, the judge's words still ring true when she states "no longer will you be a hyphenated American".  What a delightful statement for all Americans.

reviewText: This is one of Robin Williams' earliest films, and great even now, nearly thirty years later.  This may be one of the last really unabashedly pro-American movies to come out of Hollywood, and is a real gem.Robin Williams plays Vladimir, a jazz saxophonist who, on a state-sponsored tour of the "decadent" United States, winds up defecting in Bloomingdale's.  Befriended by a security guard and a perfume saleswoman, Vladimir's journey to join the freedom of the United States, and all the lessons he learns along the way to that freedom, are stirring and heartwarming."Moscow On The Hudson" is not solely, or even mainly, a comedy.  There are some very funny moments, such as Vlad's hyperventilation when he goes to buy coffee and sees shelves and shelves of different brands, with no waiting lines (as shown while he is in Russia).  Other moments are more poignant and touching.  There is little to laugh at in Moscow, at the time laboring under a repressive Communist regime.  A later scene showing several immigrants taking their oaths of citizenship to the United States is particularly stirring.  The end of the movie is filled with hope and a call to remember the reasons this is such a great country.The casting is filled with excellent performances.  This was Maria Conchita Alonso's first movie, and she is very appealing as the Italian immigrant who has some romantic leanings towards Vlad.  Cleavant Derricks ("Sliders", "Dreamgirls") is excellent, too.  Alejandro Rey plays Vlad's Cuban immigration attorney.  Russian comedic actor Savely Kramarov, who left the USSR because it was so repressive, ironically plays one of the KGB handlers Vlad has to evade to defect.Buy this movie.  This is one of Williams' best roles, and the preparations he made for it, including learning Russian and how to play the saxophone, are just one facet of how well suited he was for the part.  As for the rest, Moscow On the Hudson is a celebration of America, and of one man's spirit yearning for freedom.
summary: A Great Movie About Becoming American

reviewText: In those times of great political changes, where the use of the term Perestroika was very common, this film somehow fostered voluntary or involuntarily, the visible contradictions between West and East, when a musician remains shocked because of the wonders of Bloomingdale's department store. This caustic metaphor lets us to get inside a romantic comedy, plenty of ingenious dialogues. Obviously the direction of this smart director, the talent of Robin Williams and the alluring presence of Maria Conchita Alonso, were fundamental pillars in the striking success of this film, that dated us back to other two similar and winning works: Comrade X (1940) and Ninotchka (1939).
summary: The great artistic lap in Robin Williams' career!

reviewText: they have a maxim in the business: dying is easy, comedy is hard. i know, i know, it's hardly the wittiest witticism ever quipped. if you have a sense of humor of your own, then you're going "okaaaaay...but how about something like 'differential calculus is easy, comedy is hard?' or maybe 'building a suspension bridge is easy, comedy is hard?' i mean come on, dying? DYING? dying IS easy. all you have to do is stop breathing. it's usually not even VOLUNTARY, for cryin' out loud, how difficult could it possibly be?"but it's remembered because, flat as it falls in the joke department, it's general message is dead on the moey. one of my foremost pet-peeves is the misconception that comedy is less of an art form that drama. this is not true if only for the fact that comedy is many, many, MANY times the more difficult. i don't mean to suggest that drama is something any random bozo off the street can do, but provided said bozo has some degree of intelligence, drama is something that he can be TAUGHT. whereas comedy is purely instinctual. drama can be GIVEN TO YOU, whereas with comedy, you either got it or you ain't, PERIOD.take the case of one Leslie Neilsen. he took a part in a little film called AIRPLANE!, and as a result his career was shoved into overdrive at an age when conventional wisdom is that it should've been beginning to wind down. Neilsen next joined the AIRPLANE! production team for POLICE SQUAD! and/or THE NAKED GUN...and within a few short years he had gone from sort of famous dramatic actor to household name comedic actor. everyone of a certain age (a dozen or so certain ages, really) remembers this, and they remember it for one very simple reason: it doesn't happen very often.by comparison you frequently hear about actors you associate with comedy taking dramatic roles - about Richard Pryor's apparance on CHICAGO HOPE, for instance, or Jerry Lewis appearing on LAW & ORDER - but you seldom hear much about it, say, a month after the episode in question airs. people within the Industry are always saying that every, EVERY, comedic actor is capable of drama, but that it doesn't always work the other way around. an established comedic actor playing a dramatic role is comparable to an established brain surgeon giving you a tetanus shot.but of course there are no absolutes in this world, are there? if there were my favorite Robin Williams movie certainly wouldn't be the home of his single finest DRAMATIC performance. or, what with the film being a "dramedy," should i call it his finest "dramamedic" performance?(well technically, my favorite film that Williams was involved with would be THE ADVENTURES OF BARON MUCHAUSEN, but that film is really more synoymous with director Terry Gilliam, to say nothing of the fact that Williams is in about ten minutes of the 2-hour-6-and-1/2-minute film. but that's another issue...)MOSCOW ON THE HUDSON is a poingnant, thought-provoking tale of a Russian defector's attempts to process and integrate himself into the Free World. (back when there was a "Cold War," rememeber.) some will inevitably claim that as a drama it requires him to shift gears completely, but those bozos are full of it. comedy is almost never pure lunacy for pure lunacy's sake. comedies often allow for somber, even depressing, moments. the cast of, say, YOUNG FRANKENSTEIN are required to carry, and use, just as much emotional weight, as much "baggage," as the cast of CITIZEN KANE. sitcoms going back to THE HONEYMOONERS and GILLIGAN'S ISLAND have depicted cases of weighty questions to be asked and foolhardy characters having to pay the price for their little goof-ups. and even the driest of dramatic series have been known to shoehorn in occasional "comic relief." comedy is a sibling, not an adversary, of drama.so MOSCOW ON THE HUDSON is a serious but peppy film, headlined by an actor who was right in his element from the get-go. at a strictly clinical level, there is no surprise whatsoever in the fact that Williams can pull it off. but there is one surprise, namely the fact he handles it in such a way that you never once find yourself anticipating the usually inevitable scene in which Williams goes gonzo-chamelion on the audience, nor do you particularly miss it when you realize it's not there.a minor victory for the drama snobs, but i guess it is a victory nonetheless.
summary: Artful Storytelling From Both Sides Of The Fence!!

reviewText: For many years, I counted Moscow on the Hudson as my favorite film and if you like to be mildy entertained while considering what it means to be free in the USA, you may also love this thoughtful comedy. This was the first film that broke whatever box folks might have been trying to put Robin Williams in (after Mork and Mindy) and added Actor with a capital A to the public perception of him (at least for those who had the chance to see Moscow).Among my favorite lines in the film is the disenchanted emigree played by Robin in a blue moment saying "When I was in Russia, I loved my misery, because it was mine." I think of this when I meet people whose eyes are closed to how precious our freedom is and the cost we must pay to learn to respect and treasure it.There are many great scenes worth the wait, such as the final statement scene in the diner where other Russians who have learned how to deal with freedom, set the little Russian straight.This is not an action filled or laugh filled romp. It is a film that requires a little patience and reflection, but an illumination to those with an open mind. Bravo Mazursky and Williams!
summary: Freedom isn't free and other things to think about ..........

reviewText: This is one of those films that when channel surfing always compelled me to put down the remote control and watch. Robin Williams is excellent as a jazz enthusiast Russian immigrant, who defected to America for the purpose of artistic freedom. Williams is always believable in his depiction of vulnerability and innocence. He soon discovers the America that lies beneath the hype, warts and all. But it is his triumph that we root for and celebrate, as he slowly becomes one of us - or should I say U.S.
Title: N/A

reviewText: "Moscow on the Hudson" is not a perfect movie, but it's definitely a more thoughtful, intelligent movie than you might otherwise expect.  Robin Williams' performance as a Russian jazz musician defecting to America is sensitive and full-bodied, full of the talent and charm that make him so good to watch.  The story is a rollercoaster of moments which reflect the American experience seen through the eyes of someone thrust suddenly in the middle of it all, in the place where it is at its most insane and most wonderful: New York City.There's a line near the end of the film which struck me as particuarly adroit: "In Moscow, we fight for a crumb of freedom! Here, you s*** on it!"  It really can't be said any better than that, and the movie is filled with moments which illustrate what makes America such a great, rich, and sometimes frightening experience, and what makes freedom such an important, and sometimes dangerous, concept.Freedom is playing "Take the A-Train" on your sax, on a fire escape in New York City in the middle of the day for all the world to hear. Freedom is getting mugged on a city street at 2 AM. Freedom is getting into a stupid fight with your girlfriend, and making up with her later. Freedom is too many brands of coffee at the store, and not knowing which one to choose.  Freedom is getting drunk and laughing your head off.  Freedom is choosing not to work, even when you could. Freedom is not knowing what comes next."Moscow on the Hudson" is sometimes funny, sometimes sad, and almost always smartly-observed. Mostly, it's a movie about freedom -- not in the meaningless context that we hear politicians and pundits talk about it, but it the real, everyday sense, the things that showcase the idea of freedom in all its liberating, chaotic, messy glory.
summary: The Ups and Downs of Freedom

reviewText: This is not a great movie but definitely a sleeper. Robin Williams does a fine job as a jazz musician from Russia who deeply desires the freedom--and gets his chance--to play in America. The scene where he and his bandmates are being briefed by the KGB before traveling to New York is priceless, especially where the head agent pronounces Greenwich Village as "green-Vich Ill-yage". But the most priceless scene is where Robin Williams does defect in that greatest symbol of all American democracy and capitalism, Bloomingdales. From there, the movie teeter-totters between a comedy of cultures and some soppy sentimentality. Still, this is a movie well worth seeing, expecially for those of us who remember the dawning of glasnost

reviewText: There are plenty of movies with distinctive or amusing characters where, by the time the film is over, it seems that you don't know any of the characters.  MOSCOW ON THE HUDSON is not this type of movie.  MOSCOW ON THE HUDSON is noted for having at least a half-dozen recurring characters.  By the time the film is reaching its conclusion, one feels that one knows all of them.The story concerns a small Russian circus, and its musical ensemble, about to embark on goodwill visit and performance in New York City.  The viewer is treated to a generous dose of the usual Russian stereotypes, e.g., long lines of people waiting to buy humble commodities, paranoia regarding the KGB, dancing bears, and ugly chunky women. A vital point in the introductory hour, is Robin Williams' admiration for American jazz.  To untrained ears, his Russian accent sounds authentic.The circus troupe reaches New York City, and during a stopover at Bloomingdale's, Robin Williams breaks away and tries to defect.  He succeeds.  As the film moves onward, it becomes a veritable textbook of relationships: (1) Robin Williams and his host family in America, (2) Robin Williams and department store security guard, (3) Host family's strong mother versus host family's jobless father, (4) Robin Williams and ugly chunky girlfriend in Russia, (5) Robin Williams and beautiful and less chunky Italian girlfriend in New York, (6) Robin Williams and his Russian circus clown buddy, (7) Robin Williams and his grandfather in Russia, (8) Italian girlfriend and her Italian family, and (9) Robin Williams and his Cuban attorney.  To repeat, I am not sure how the scriptwriter and director did it, but this film establishes a little collection of distinctive relationships, each having its own place in the narrative.As mentioned above, the first half of the movie takes place in Russia.  The second half takes place in New York City, apparently in lower Manhattan.  I have toured lower Manhattan several times, that is, the area between the ferry boat terminal and Houston Street, as well as Greenwich Village.  I enjoyed the accurate portrayals of the sidewalk vendors.The movie actually teaches a lesson, namely, the delicate task of severing one's roots, and of the phenomenon of returning to one's roots.  The movie is mostly a happy one, and it does have a happy ending.
Title: N/A

reviewText: MonH is funny, touching, and more or less credible, as far as the life in the Soviet Union goes.Robin Williams, who never ceases to amaze, speaks Russian and plays sax in this film. He mamages to re-create general "Soviet Man" image without many common stereotypes.Most of the film's story is actually true, based on the life of an immigrant jazz-musician, who is still alive and well. In 70s, this man managed to leave Soviet Union and settled in New York.The title sums up the story nicely, too.
summary: One of the best roles for Robin Willims so far...
